instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Fixed blown cap and resistor and still has issues.
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a

<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Fixed blown cap and resistor and still issues.

Came in no boot. Removed logic board and found <CAPACITOR>C7536</CAPACITOR> blown, <CAPACITOR>C7537</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7536</RESISTOR> looked like hell.

Replaced them both, and unit had fan spin.  Reassembled unit and no boot ?

Ok, let's take it back apart. Power supply shows 0.09A draw.  Light goes green, then orange.  After a quick wander, again 0.09A

What I do find odd, SSD gets warm, however no chime, no fan and CPU is cold.

Thoughts from here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Fixed blown cap and resistor and still has issues.
threads.message:
What voltages do you get on the big coils?
Use original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Fixed blown cap and resistor and still has issues.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Fixed blown cap and resistor and still has issues.
threads.message:
So you have only <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>; what about <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Fixed blown cap and resistor and still has issues.
threads.message:
Checked <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> @ 

<CHIP>U6100</CHIP> pin 8 ,<CAPACITOR>C6100</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR>, <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> Pin 2, <RESISTOR>R8133</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R1583</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R1581</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R1590</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R1580</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C1206</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C1202</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C1204</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R1549</RESISTOR>, R152.

All pined @ 3.3V

 I'm a bit green..  Would need help with " Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> " 

Not sure how this is done?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Fixed blown cap and resistor and still has issues.
threads.message:
I hope this thread helps you:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

BTW, no need to measure the voltage of a power rail in more than one point.

In case you detect drop pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> too (at same time).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Fixed blown cap and resistor and still has issues.
threads.message:
That document most definitely helped me, big thanks !  Do we have an area for docs like this ?

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>   : Both pulse when I ground <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL>.

 It drawn a little more power briefly, then goes back to drawing 0.09A

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Fixed blown cap and resistor and still has issues.
threads.message: I also believe I may have goofed. It appears I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> if that changes anything. Not sure the difference? They are crazy similar. I just noticed a few components looked to be missing on this board Vs my schematics Though same solder points. . This <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> seems to be the one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Fixed blown cap and resistor and still has issues.
threads.message:
Check for pulse at all big coils; at same time when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
Also check <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> for pulse.
Inspect <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> for corrosion.

Test strating in SMC bypass mode, just in case.
